comments.body: I'm not sure I see the reason for editing something in a beta api like this?

the `(beta)` here indicates the status of the `DynamicKubeletConfig` feature. I suggest to highlight the fact that the feature will be gone soon. Alternatively, I can change `(deprecated)` to something like `to be removed`?
Presumably in v1beta1 it was beta, though? I don't know if I object, this just seems like modifying the past...

I understand. It is a valid point. However, the problem is that when feature will be removed, this API behavior will also change retroactively. This is why I think it makes sense to update the description now.
OK

I found the `Dynamic Kubelet Config (deprecated)` comments here confusing, because for a moment I thought it implied the `KubeletConfig` was being deprecated.

@SergeyKanzhelev I would suggest that we _remove_ all mention of DynamicKubeletConfig from the KubeletConfig comments here instead. Since it's being deprecated, IMO this advice is no longer relevant, and since KubeletConfig is a beta API I think we can change this.

I think it's good to document the current state even if that is confusing. I agree it could be worded better, e.g. "If DynamicKubeletConfig (deprecated; default off) is on, then ..."

I don't feel too strongly. The pre-existing sentences are not super clear, either.
I can send the proposed clarified text as a separate PR.
note this required the SeccompDefault feature gate?
Yep, added a comment as suggested :+1:

One small thought I have while reviewing your PR: We might want to differentiate system-cluster-critical from system-node-critical. We might want to gracefully terminate the normal pods and system-cluster-critical pods first, then terminate system-node-critical pods. But I am ok with the current approach for now.

Thanks Dawn for taking a look. Good point, both categories of critical pods are included in this duration. 

I agree this something we can re-evaluate in beta of the feature and determine if it's worth splitting these two categories out during shutdown.
Where is the validation logic for this field?  I didn't see it in this PR

- the parsing logic for the CLI placed under the flag `Set()` method - https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/95479/commits/6778d70f87374b0d25405727de083a8739125d40#diff-5ce184b1c6db0f7a5e25ba8283097c283ae66c084640be3cd4f17c71cb7ff111R163
- more robust validation logic handled under the memory manager during the creation of the `MemoryManager` instance(similar to the CPU manager), you can find it under https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/95479/files#diff-501be18894cc46e590062eb7d2a32948635de2de8bcc8baf4a44cf3916dea084R358

If this says it defaults to `"text"`, I expected to see defaulting in staging/src/k8s.io/component-base/config/v1alpha1/defaults.go that set that default. That might also let us drop the conditional `if s.Logging.Format != "" {` checks before applying the config format to the log options.
Fixed.
The field requires validation.

good reminder. will add it in two place: validation.go and server.go. In validation phase check it is a valid cpu list string, also make sure user does not intent to use  --kube-reserved-cgroup nor  --system-reserved-cgroup with the specific cpulist; in server.go make sure the cpulist is supported by the machine. If none of these condition meet, always take the old behavior
updated
document the default uses the explicit `nodeStatusUpdateFrequency` value if provided, otherwise, 1m
include the improved documentation about what happens if a status update is computed in this comment as well
Done
